Headline.Para: The Straits Times says; Justice that's in step with the times

LeadPara.Para: The wheels of criminal justice might move slowly and fitfully when insufficient attention is paid to the system as a whole. In Britain, for example, a parliamentary committee warned two years ago that its overstretched system was "close to breaking point". And in Canada, justice ministers had emergency meetings last year when excessive delays prompted an apex court ruling that led to serious criminal charges, including murder cases, being thrown out as a result of unreasonable waiting periods. The American system is flawed too, according to some critics who view it as "neither too lenient nor too punitive, but too prone to both extremes". At times, calls for systemic reform might arise when abuse surfaces - like the stripping, beating and gassing of children under detention in Australia's Northern Territory.

TailParas.Para: The recurring nature of such debates over the years reflects both the grinding pace of change in many places and the tension between two competing aims. Foremost is the instrumental purpose of criminal justice, which is to deter criminal behaviour and reduce the incidence of crime. The emphasis here is on effective policing methods, rigorous prosecution, and appropriate punishment for offenders.

Alongside such pressing concerns is the intrinsic purpose of criminal justice, which is to ensure fairness and reliability, and to improve human outcomes. This goes beyond setting up a well-oiled machinery to deal with crime efficiently and effectively. While that is a desirable goal, the system must also strive for fairness - due process of law, a right to a fair trial, sound evidentiary standards, and the presence of checks and balances. Similarly, when enforcing punishment, one should not lose sight of rehabilitation, as re-socialising offenders can help them to become functioning members of society. The human dimension of criminal justice ought to also encompass access to justice; support for victims; means of healing relationships wrecked by crime; compensation for those harmed by criminal activity; and steps to prevent the system from acting to the disadvantage of some groups but not others.

The recent changes to Singapore's criminal justice framework demonstrate the avowed long-term push here towards a "more progressive, balanced and modern" system, as the Law Ministry put it. A focus on the intrinsic purpose of justice is evident in provisions on the fairness of procedures, accuracy and equity of outcomes. Examples include better protection for vulnerable victims, video statements by suspects (long advocated by lawyers), and the extension to more offences of the pre-trial disclosure of exhibits and witnesses. In the past, the accused learnt such details only at the trial. Criminal justice being a complex social institution, it is important for due process to go hand in hand with crime control.
